we're joined by Adora and Avichal and I'll leave it to them to

Adora Cheung. I am a partner at Y Combinator. Previously I had a, I was a founder
CEO of a startup called Homejoy.

of product at Facebook.

Done a couple startups,
sold a couple, invested in a bunch. [BLANK AUDIO]

>> Hello, Adora.
Nice to meet you. >> Avichal, good to meet you. >> Adora. Nice to meet you. >> Avichal, good to meet you.
>> Cool, welcome, so, tell us what you do. Hi, we're working on Appmission.

It's a web application
that offers high quality, personalized college admission advice for
high school student.

>> So is it a, is there not a person
on the other end, or how does the? Can you give the most common
use case of how people use it?

>> So a student can sign up for free,
and then they will create a profile. >> The profile includes the academic
information, including the GPA it

has scores, and also extracurricular
activities, and the college goals. For example, the colleges that
they want to get into, and

also the majors they are interested in. So once they enter the data,
we generate algorithm to-.

We use our algorithm to generate
a personalized recommendations to them to help them reach their goals.

>> Gotcha, so who's using this or
who do you want to use this? >> The high school students and
their parents. >> Who more specifically?

>> For those who cannot afford
private college counseling because that is the price range is
from 4,000 to $40,000 per package.
>> I see. >> And why would they use this?

>> Because in the U.S. public high school,
one counselor serves 491 students, and

each student only get 38 minutes
of college advising per year. So we want to fill in the gap so
they can get access and

we think that every student deserve
the help they need to get into college. >> Is there one particular thing
that they really need help on?

Because one of the things I

objective in standard, right? So do you find there's a specific feature
that people are really looking for

We talked about our essays,
we talked about college selections. But recently,
when we talked to some of the users,

we found out that they want
one on one interactions. And specifically on college selection and
the essay.

which we just kind of did it on our own.

The back end is us but actually we talked

>> It's going quicker than I expected. So we, for the past three days we
had about 800 people visit the site.

And then we had 60,
about 60 advisors signed up. So right now, because of marketplace,
we focus on the supply side first.

Like personalized learning and

they focus really on tutoring. They've put a lot of those energy

then they feel like they

personal advice from the friends or family or

because my first startup was in education,

And so there's a leap that sometimes

that's why I was sort of probing on it.

I was like has the market

there is reason change that I think, will give us a opportunity

they don't currently get it today? >> Right.
They get very minimal.

>> Yeah.
>> [LAUGH] So what are they using right now? >> Right.
So there are a lot of free sites out there like college for,
they have check.

They have different websites that tells

But those are not personalized for them. And when we did an interview

basically people that we know.

>> Yeah.
I keep coming back to this. I think specifically, this is one of the
biggest risks in the education market is

that the mass market is going to behave

what you want to build for those people and what they want is

probably think about education very

similar to the way you do. Or your friend's kids probably think

the site to see which one

so that we can just
focus on that one thing. >> Yeah.
Have you guys considered the international markets at all?

Is this just a U.S.

States first, that was the focus.

there is the need, but

your site right now? >> We have about 200 students on site.

>> 200 students, and what's the common

so that tells me that they're pretty,

they wait until pretty
last minute to do this. And then 25% the junior.

A majority of them are focusing on
computer science, and engineering, math type, and business majors.

>> It sounds like you might want to, and I think this is kind of what Avichal

what is that core thing that they
really need, versus just like. Right now it seems a little abstract of,
I'm going to help you find a college, but

it might be something as simple as
the essay, like I need help on the essay. And just focus on that one thing, and

doing some many things at once. >> So our mission is to basically
make sure that we provide the same

within maybe California,

maybe in bigger cities that
students are more educated. They have the background of
what's the path to college.

And beyond that what we are trying to do,
again you know going back to mission, we want to make sure that outside
of these group of students,

people from outside California also have
the same access to the same information. I mean if you think about or
actually based on our survey or

talking to users we know that
a lot of students actually think they might not even have the chance
to into colleges because it

might not be affordable to them, right? But there is definitely alternatives for

things like that. That's the tier that
we're trying to target, to make sure that they have
access to that information.

So that they know they at least have
the chance to apply to college, and maybe qualify for financial aid and path.

>> I'm just going to echo what
I think Adora's saying is, I love what you said by the way. Like that's an awesome mission, right? And so there's, when you think about
a company there's like the mission,

there's the vision. Like when we achieve the mission
here's what the world will look like. There's the strategy, which is like, here's how we're going to,
in the fewest number of words,

how we're going to go about achieving our
mission, and then there's the tactics. There's the things that
you do week over week in

pursuit of your strategy to validate

Where it's like okay, great, that's

then you've created all of the value for

there's many steps in that and

they need the most help and
which they will actually pay for as well, because you're trying, obviously,

>> And, it's not just product strategy.

There's also the go to market strategy,

people even that take the SAT in the US?

Right?
It's like half the people don't even take the SAT, right? So you're talking about large numbers
of people at every step of the funnel.

And so who you target is also part of your

those people as the first step.

>> Yeah, I think that's a great point and
when we first started there are like many different angles we can target,

we want to just ask the users to
drive us to which is the focus. And I felt like because the early

Some early indication is
school selection and essay. So these are the two so far that I can

and business. So those are three majors. So we have some pieces of signals
that tell us which way we should go.

But I know, in my heart, that going forward there is some,
one area that I need to focus on.

I feel like we don't have
enough data to get there yet. >> Yeah, well, the challenge of data,
this goes back to

there is two ways to figure
out what you want to build, whether it's your go to market plan,
your product is the top down.

Which is you go get a bunch of data. Where are the opportunities? How do you slice the market? We're going to start here and
then we're going to go here and then we're going to go here.

Or bottoms up which is you build
the thing, you put it out there, people start using it. They're like we want this. We move forward.

And a lot of software actually bottoms up,
is great. Because the early adopters indicate where
the world is headed as we build for

them and then the rest of
the world kind of catches up. It's like social networking,
obviously is a great example of that.

The challenge is if the people that are
the early adopters of your product are not representative of what
everybody else is going to do,

then you end up building a thing that
doesn't actually work for everybody else. And that's, I think, part of the challenge
that you would have right now if you do

that is, I suspect the people that
are coming to you are not going to be 100% representative. To me it sounds like two different populations of
people that you're talking about.

The people who don't know about financial
aid and maybe are not applying to colleges and not doing all this kind of stuff and
don't have the support, versus like

people who are organically finding
this and care about this stuff a lot. Like to me it actually sounds like
different populations of people.

>> Okay, I think we have to finish up,

>> What are you guys working on? >> So I'm Sid and I'm the CEO and
co-founder of Yembo.

At Yembo, we are bringing computer
vision technology to solve the price and cost estimation problem for
the home services market,

specifically we are starting
with the moving industry. So let's say you are consumer and
you want to move, and

you want to know how
much it's going to cost. You take a video and our technology
will identify all the items, and then,

you get an upfront and accurate quote. So this is much better than
calling multiple moving companies,

staying on the phone for about half an
hour each to get arbitrary ground codes, or waiting at home for
on site estimator to come visit.

>> So is this an app? >> So we-
>> Sure. And we have multiple channels,
we did an NVP pilot with an app.

We've also been working on just
having it directly on the web page of the moving company. >> So say, I'm at home, it sounds like I
take the app and I'm taking pictures and

I'm sending it to you guys and then,
you kind of give me an estimate ASAP, essentially, okay.

>> Correct, yeah, and we also have a solution where

this is more accurate than the, or

what's the percent of accuracy do

we are targeting the same accuracies.

So the way we are thinking about it
is today the estimation process takes about a week for you to get a quote or
you get multiple quotes and

you don't really understand
why a quote is what it is. So our goal is to give you a complete
breakdown on what it is, and we still have

some human labor in the background,
cleaning up the mistakes the AI is making.

So our goal is to reduce the human
time to less than five minutes. >> Why is it so expensive,
or why is it so,

take a week to get a quote like
where moving take coming along? >> So one main reason is if you are
scheduling an onsite estimator with it.

So it costs the moving company a lot,
more than $200 for a visit. And you have to schedule
someone to come visit.

And these guys are able to
do 2 to 3 estimates a day. So in summertime and it's busy,
it gets really backed up.

So most companies don't end up actually
sending an on-site estimator, and they give price quotes over the phone.

Our research shows that 90% of this was
wrong, so consumers shop around and that they don't really understand why
a companies quoting what they're quoting.

And in a lot of cases what happens
is there are these predatory providers in the market who take
advantage of this price opaqueness and

they give you a low ball quote,
get your business, and on the day of your move specifically,
they slap you with last minute fee hikes.

So we want to eliminate all of that. >> So once you get the quote are you

So we are not a moving company, and

well what does the computer

and

also you need to hire and
scale human workforce to do that. And there are a few other

So our goal is, we eliminate like
majority of the work through using CV

and keep the human workload
to as less possible. And from a product perspective
what we want to be also able

to deliver to consumers is a interactively
of them customizing their quote. So let's say you have a $2,000 budget and
everything,

moving everything is maybe
going to cost $3,000. Then you can decide, pick and

company in San Diego. There, we are doing this GPM solution

$50 with AI and
a we are talking to multiple large growing companies from $20 million

Is it accuracy or
